description.p: The slender elf cleaned her glasses with the corner of her cloak, as the dust began to settle around her. Her benefactor had paid her a handsome sum to locate this forgotten place, and after months of pouring over ancient tomes, she finally pieced together it's long-lost location. Now, she had a difficult choice to make. If she reported her findings to her benefactor, the temple would be stripped of its valuables. If she kept the location of her discovery hidden, then she could preserve the priceless knowledge contained within. For to a savant, knowledge is more precious then gold coins.

The elderly human warrior assessed the state of the soldiers under his command. They were exhausted and almost out of supplies. It was the tenth day of the siege, and the old warrior knew in his heart that no reinforcements would be coming to save them. He was too old to be of much use in battle, but if his soldiers followed his orders to the letter, and without hesitation, they just might have a fighting chance. He stood up, and for what could be the last time, donned his shield and drew his sword from its scabbard.

A young dwarf bent over his unconscious comrade in the midst of battle, his hands were shaking as he examined the unconscious soldier's wounds. The elders of his clan had spent a great deal of their fortune to send him to the best university gold could buy. All those hours spent in lectures, libraries, and observation, all for this moment. He thought back to all he had learned about field medicine and began to dress his comrade's wounds.

There are many intelligent people in the world, but few are true savants. Born with an innate desire to learn all they can, and the potential for a genius level intellect, savants spend their lives studying anything that those around them are willing to teach. Often recognized at an early age, their ravenous hunger for knowledge, draws them to great libraries, universities, and other places of higher learning. Willing to go to any lengths to access the hidden knowledge of the world, savants often turn to a life of adventuring. For a savant, no price is too steep to pay for a new discovery.

Despite their aptitude for learning, most savants seek to better themselves without having to depend other forces. Rejecting the patronage of powerful beings, and considering wizardry a shortcut to power, savants rely on their intellect alone, as they strive for perfection.

Savants hyper-focus on their area of academic study. They obsess and learn all they can about their area of expertise. This drive fuels every savant, and they are willing to put aside political, religious, or cultural divisions in order to learn. Once they have learned all academia can teach them, savants strike out into the world to advance their field of study .

Often at great cost to themselves, a savant will not stop researching, experimenting, and theorizing until they have made an indelible mark on their academic discipline. Whether they realize it or not, the ultimate goal burning within the heart of every savant is to uncover some lost or previously unknown truth about the universe.

When creating your savant, consider their upbringing and level of formal education. Were they the star pupil of the kingdom's university, or did they come from squal, fighting for any scrap of knowledge they could get their hands on? Consider why they became an adventurer rather than an academic. Have they advanced beyond study and look to the endless discoveries of a life of adventure?

You can make a savant quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Intelligence your highest ability score, followed by Dexterity. Second, choose the noble or sage background from the Player's Handbook.
If your group uses the optional rule for multiclassing in the Player's Handbook, here's what you need to know if you choose the savant as one of your classes.
Ability Score Minimum. As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 in Intelligence to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are a savant.

Proficiencies Gained. If savant isn't your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a savant: one skill from the savant skill list and one set of artisan's tools of your choice.
As an savant, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per savant level after 1st
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: One set of artisan's tools of your choice
Skills: Choose two from Arcana, History, Insight, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Persuasion, Religion, and Sleight of Hand

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) two simple weapons of your choice or (b) a rapier.
(a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) a shortsword.
one set of artisan's tools of your choice.
leather armor and a scholar's pack.

setters.set: If savant isn't your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a savant: one skill from the savant skill list and one set of artisan's tools of your choice.

description.p: You can analyze the movement patterns and fighting style of your foe to discern information and land precise strikes. Starting at 1st-level, you can use a bonus action to mark a creature within 60 feet, that you can see, as the target of your Adroit Analysis. Whenever you make a weapon attack against the marked creature, you can use your Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls.

This mark lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you choose to end it as a bonus action, you are incapacitated, or you mark another creature as the target. If you mark another creature any effects immediately end for the previous target.

In addition, you can make use of your finely honed skills, even in the midst of battle. As a bonus action on your turn, you can make an ability check using any Intelligence or Wisdom-based skill with which you have proficiency.

sheet.description: You can mark a creature within 60 feet, that you can see. Whenever you make a weapon attack against the marked creature, you can use your Intelligence (+{{intelligence:modifier}}), in place of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls.

description.p: Your hyper-observant way of fighting allows you to predict enemy attacks and quickly react to avoid being hit when unencumbered. Beginning at 1st level, when you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your Armor Class is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier.

sheet.description: When you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your Armor Class is {{ac:unarmored defense savant}}.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, your photographic memory allows you to remember even the most minute details from things that you've studied. If you spend at least 1 minute observing and committing something to memory, you can automatically recall any information about your observations at any point in the future without requiring an ability check.
For example, you can perfectly recall the details of a book you've read, a map you've examined, a person's appearance, the contents of a speech, or paths you've traveled.

sheet.description: If you spend at least 1 minute observing and committing something to memory, you can automatically recall any information about your observations at any point in the future without requiring an ability check.

description.p: By 2nd level, your mind has been honed into both a potent analytical weapon and a stalwart shield against mental assaults. When you make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma check or saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the result of the ability check or saving throw. You use this feature after you roll, but before you know whether you succeed or fail.
The size of the unyielding mind die you roll for this feature increases when you reach certain levels in this class; to 1d6 at 10th-level, 1d8 at 15th-level, and 1d10 at 20th-level.

sheet.description: When you make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma check or saving throw, you can roll a d{{unyielding-mind:die-type}} and add the number rolled to the result of the ability check or saving throw. You use this feature after you roll, but before you know whether you succeed or fail.

description.p: The focus of their considerable intellect, a savant's Academic Discipline is not a decision they make lightly. At 3rd level, you choose your Academic Discipline. Choose between Archaeologist, Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, Seeker, or Tactician, each of which is detailed at the end of the class description. Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 7th, 13th, and 17th level.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Your ability to process, and react to, the world around you is notably faster then most mortal creatures. Upon reaching 5th level, you can take one additional reaction per round. A single effect can only trigger one of your reactions.
Starting at 17th level, your ability to process stimuli grows, allowing you another reaction per round (for a total of 3).

sheet.description: You can take one additional reaction per round. A single effect can only trigger one of your reactions.
You can take two additional reactions per round. A single effect can only trigger one of your reactions.

description.p: Starting at 5th level, you can use your acute observational skills to highlight the weak points of your foes for your allies. When you, or a creature that you can see, hits the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack, you can use your reaction to increase the damage dealt by the attack by 1d10. If the attack deals more than one type of damage, the attacking creature chooses which type of damage to increase.
Beginning at 11th level, you offer keener observations and the bonus damage from this feature increases to 2d10.

sheet.description: When you, or a creature that you can see, hits the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack, you can increase the damage dealt by the attack by {{potent-observation:damage-dice}}d10. If the attack deals more than one type of damage, the attacking creature chooses which type of damage to increase.

description.p: Upon reaching 6th level, your ability to master new skills is unrivaled. At the end of a short or long rest, you can choose to learn one additional language, or gain one tool, skill, or weapon proficiency of your choice, as long as there is an example on hand for you to learn from (such as a teacher, a manual, a book in a different language, or a party member with the proficiency). You can gain only one bonus proficiency or language from this feature per each short or long rest.

You can have a total number of bonus proficiencies and languages from this feature equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). If you learn another proficiency or language while at your maximum you must choose one proficiency or language you gained from this feature to forget. You immediately lose any knowledge and benefits from it.

sheet.description: At the end of a short or long rest, you can choose to learn one additional language, or gain one tool, skill, or weapon proficiency of your choice, as long as there is an example on hand for you to learn from (such as a teacher, a manual, a book in a different language, or a party member with the proficiency). You can gain only one bonus proficiency or language from this feature per each short or long rest. You can have up to {{int-mod:min-one}} bonus proficiencies at a time.

description.p: Beginning at 9th level, your ability to pass knowledge to others is peerless. At the end of a long rest, choose one skill, tool, or weapon proficiency or language you know. A number of creatures that can hear you, equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), gain that proficiency or language. This benefit lasts until the end of your next long rest.
The proficiency or language you choose to teach with this feature can be one that you've acquired from expert student.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, choose one skill, tool, or weapon proficiency or language you know (including those from Expert Student). Up to {{int-mod:min-one}} creatures that can hear you gain that proficiency or language. This benefit lasts until the end of your next long rest.

description.p: You can identify the weak points of a creature without prior analysis. Starting at 11th level, you can use your Potent Observation reaction when a creature you can see hits another creature with a weapon attack, even if the target of the attack is not the target of your Adroit Analysis. You must be able to see both creatures to use this reaction.

In addition, if you use your Potent Observation reaction when a creature hits the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack they gain an additional bonus to their damage roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

sheet.description: You can use your Potent Observation reaction when a creature you can see hits another creature with a weapon attack, even if the target of the attack is not the target of your Adroit Analysis. You must be able to see both creatures to use this reaction. In addition, if you use your Potent Observation reaction when a creature hits the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack they gain an additional +{{int-mod:min-one}} bonus to their damage roll.

description.p: Starting at 14th level, you can steel your mind against effects that remove your mental agency. If you fail a saving throw to resist being charmed, frightened, or stunned, you can choose to automatically succeed on the saving throw instead.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: If you fail a saving throw to resist being charmed, frightened, or stunned, you can choose to automatically succeed on the saving throw instead.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, your unequaled ability to process the world around you allows you to predict your enemy's attacks as they happen. The target of your Adroit Analysis has disadvantage on any attack targeting you, and you have advantage on any saving throws it forces you to make.

sheet.description: The target of your Adroit Analysis has disadvantage on any attack targeting you, and you have advantage on any saving throws it forces you to make.

description.p: Upon reaching 20th level, you realize the wondrous potential of your intellect. Your Intelligence and Wisdom scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

Specializing in the study of forgotten civilizations, ancient places, and uncharted lands, Archaeologists boldly walk into the dark and deadly places of the world that they may be illuminated by the light of knowledge. Archaeologists do their best to piece together the lost knowledge of past ages. They tend to feel a sad kinship with the lost civilizations that they study, and will go to great lengths not to destroy or offend their memory. For an Archaeologist, learning from the innovations, and mistakes, of the past is the best way to improve the present and move toward a better future.

Starting at 3rd level, your study of bygone eras allows you unique insight into ancient and forgotten things. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you learn two languages of your choice and you gain proficiency in the History and Investigation skills. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either History or Investigation. If you are already proficient in either of these two skills you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with civilizations, both ancient and modern, allows you to learn additional information through observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis, you learn of either one language spoken by the creature, or of one of its special senses.

sheet.description: When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis, you learn of either one language spoken by the creature, or of one of its special senses.

description.p: Ancient temples and forgotten dungeons are deadly to most, but your time in such places has honed your survival instincts in comparison to other savants and academics. Starting at 3rd level, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: When prone, standing up only takes 5 feet of movement.
You can use your Unyielding Mind reaction when you make a Dexterity ability check or saving throw.

If you spend one minute examining an object, you can ascertain its approximate monetary worth, its civilization of origin, and its approximate age. If the item has any innate magical properties, you learn of them as if you had cast the identify spell on the object. Like identify, this feature doesn't allow you to discover curses.

sheet.description: When prone, standing up only takes 5 feet of movement. You can use your Unyielding Mind reaction when you make a Dexterity ability check or saving throw. If you spend one minute examining an object, you can ascertain its approximate monetary worth, its civilization of origin, and its approximate age. If the item has any innate magical properties, you learn of them as if you had cast the identify spell on the object.

description.p: You have learned to better defend yourself from the dangers that lie within the ancient places that you venture into for the sake of discovery. Starting at 7th level, when the target of your Adroit Analysis targets you with an opportunity attack it has disadvantage on the attack roll.

In addition, when you are subjected to a trap that allows you to make a saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

sheet.description: When the target of your Adroit Analysis targets you with an opportunity attack it has disadvantage on the attack roll. In addition, when you are subjected to a trap that allows you to make a saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

description.p: By 13th level, your research into lost civilizations, ancient artifacts, and forgotten rituals, has given you knowledge of the most obscure and esoteric lore. If you observe a place or object for at least one minute, you can recall information about it as if you had cast the legend lore spell.
Once you use this feature you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

In addition, you can use an instance of your Expert Student feature to attune to a magic item that you don't normally meet the alignment, class, or race requirements for. You cannot use this feature to exceed your attunement limits.

sheet.description: If you observe a place or object for at least one minute, you can recall information about it as if you had cast the legend lore spell. In addition, you can use an instance of your Expert Student feature to attune to a magic item that you don't normally meet the alignment, class, or race requirements for.

description.p: Upon reaching 17th level, your frequent exposure to the magical effects present in ancient places has caused your body to develop an innate arcane ward. You are resistant to all damage from spells and other magical effects.

sheet.description: You are resistant to all damage from spells and other magical effects.

description.p: The Naturalist's classroom begins at the very edges of civilization. They study the plants, animals, and environments that exist beyond the influence of civilization. Naturalists are experts at anticipating the weather, knowing the difference between an edible plant and a toxic one, and understanding the behaviors of wild animals. Highly sought after as guides for adventuring parties, Naturalists can safely navigate arid deserts, frigid mountain ranges, and treacherous jungles.

div.p: Naturalists thrive when they know the challenges that lie ahead. Make sure to use your considerable knowledge to anticipate any dangers that you and your companions may face on your journeys.
However, if things don't go as planned, never fear. A good Naturalist is always prepared for the worst case scenario, and their unwavering confidence can be a beacon of hope for their allies.

description.p: Beginning at 3rd level, your time studying the natural world has granted you insight into the ways of the wild. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency in the Animal Handling and Nature skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Animal Handling or Nature you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with creature types allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its creature type, its highest ability score, or its lowest ability score.

sheet.description: When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its creature type, its highest ability score, or its lowest ability score.

description.p: Starting at 3rd level, your study of flora and fauna has given you insight into their weak points. If the target of your Adroit Analysis is a beast, monstrosity, or plant, your weapon attacks against it score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

Additionally, at the end of a long rest, you can attune yourself to the natural environment you are currently in (examples include, but are not limited to, arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, jungle, mountain, swamp, or underground). While in that environment, you have advantage on any Intelligence or Wisdom checks you make related to its native animals, plants, ecosystem, or weather.

sheet.description: If the target of your Adroit Analysis is a beast, monstrosity, or plant, your weapon attacks against it score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. Additionally, at the end of a long rest, you can attune yourself to the natural environment you are currently in. While in that environment, you have advantage on any Intelligence or Wisdom checks you make related to its native animals, plants, ecosystem, or weather.

description.p: Upon reaching 7th level, you can use your knowledge of the wilderness to better prepare friendly creatures for upcoming dangers. At the end of a long rest, you can choose a number of friendly creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), you and these creatures all gain a benefit of your choice from the list below. This benefit lasts until the end of your next long rest.

Amphibious Training. Creatures gain a swimming speed equal to their movement speed and can hold their breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + their Constitution modifier + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1 minute).
Concealment Training. Creatures can move stealthily at a normal pace and can take the Hide action as a bonus action.
Endurance Training. Creatures ignore the effects of difficult terrain imposed by natural environments and their movement speed increases by 10 feet.

Harsh Environment Training. Creatures have advantage on saving throws to resist the effects of harsh environments, and they gain resistance to one of the following damage types of your choice: cold, fire, poison, lightning, or thunder.
Mountaineer Training. Creatures gain a climbing speed equal to their movement speed and they reduce any falling damage they take by an amount equal to your savant level.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you choose up to {{int-mod:min-one}} friendly creatures. You and these creatures all gain a benefit of your choice from the list below. This benefit lasts until the end of your next long rest. Amphibious Training, Concealment Training, Endurance Training, Harsh Environment Training, or Mountaineer Training

description.p: You've come to understand the plants and animals of the natural world in a way that few people do. Starting at 13th level, you can use your action to touch a beast or plant and attempt to charm it as if casting the dominate beast spell. The save DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier. Unlike the spell, this feature can affect plants as well as beasts.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You can touch a beast or plant and attempt to charm it as if casting the dominate beast spell (DC {{wild-insights:save-dc}}).

description.p: You have become a leading authority on the natural world, and can maneuver with comfort in any environment. Upon reaching 17th level, you automatically attune to your current environment for the purposes of your Adapt and Overcome feature, and you gain the benefits of all Survivalist features.

sheet.description: You automatically attune to your current environment for the purposes of your Adapt and Overcome feature, and you gain the benefits of all Survivalist features.

description.p: Philosophy is the purest Academic Discipline a savant can pursue. Philosophers spend their lives pondering the deep questions of existence; the purpose of life, the nature of the planes, and the relationship between mortals, the gods, and everything in between. Through the study of natural sciences, public speaking, and philosophy they seek to perfect their knowledge of the cosmos and their place in the reality.

When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you gain proficiency in the Arcana and Religion skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Arcana or Religion you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your time thinking on the nature of existence allows you to glean additional information by observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its plane of origin, its alignment, or its spellcasting ability (if it has one) and the level of the highest spell the creature is capable of casting.

sheet.description: When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its plane of origin, its alignment, or its spellcasting ability (if it has one) and the level of the highest spell the creature is capable of casting.

description.p: Your mastery over the spoken word and your understanding of the multiverse allows you to exert your will to influence reality in minor ways. Starting at 3rd level, when you hit a creature that is the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack, you can speak one of the words of power below, enhancing your attack. You can speak a word of power a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Saving Throws. The words of power you speak require the target to make a saving throw to resist their effects. The save DC for your words of power is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.

Confound. You speak a word of power that sows confusion in the mind of your enemy. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target must subtract your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) from all attack rolls it makes before the end of your next turn.

Debilitate. You speak a word of power that assaults your foe's senses. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target is blinded, deafened, or is unable to speak (your choice) until the end of your next turn.

Disorient. You speak a word of power that weakens the place of a creature in reality. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target must subtract your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) from all saving throws it makes before the start of your next turn.

Exhaust. You speak a word of power that drains the vitality of a foe. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target gains one level of exhaustion. If a creature has at least one level of exhaustion from this feature it can make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a successful save, any levels of exhaustion the creature has from this feature are reduced by one.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature that is the target of your Adroit Analysis with an attack, you can speak one of the words of power below, enhancing your attack. Confound, Debilitate, Disorient, or Exhaust

description.p: Beginning at 7th level, your force of will is resolute. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make an Intelligence or Wisdom saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

In addition, your mastery over your words of power has increased. When you use your Potent Observation reaction you can choose to expend one use of your Words of Power, imposing its effects on the target of the attack in addition to the bonus damage.

sheet.description: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make an Intelligence or Wisdom saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail. When you use your Potent Observation reaction you can choose to expend one use of your Words of Power, imposing its effects on the target of the attack in addition to the bonus damage.

description.p: Your knowledge of reality increases the influence of your speech. Starting at 13th level, you can speak the following words, once each, without expending a use of your Words of Power feature. Once you spoken, you must finish a short or long rest before you can speak that Word of Power again.

Banish. You speak a word of power that shunts a creature from your current plane of existence. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be banished for 1 minute. If the target is native to the plane of existence you're currently on, it is banished to a harmless Demiplane. If the target is native to a different plane of existence then the one you're on, the target is banished to its home plane. The target can make a Charisma saving throw at the end of each of its turns, returning to your plane of existence on a success.

Enfeeble. You speak a word of power that paralyzes the mind of a creature. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target is stunned for 1 minute. The target can make an Intelligence saving throw each time it takes damage, ending the effect on a success.

sheet.description: You can speak the following words, once each, without expending a use of your Words of Power feature. Banish or Enfeeble.

description.p: Even the most powerful extraplanar creatures struggle to contend with your will and sense of purpose. Upon reaching 17th level, you are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell, and when an aberration, celestial, fey, fiend, or undead creature forces you to make a saving throw, you have advantage on the roll.

sheet.description: You are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell, and when an aberration, celestial, fey, fiend, or undead creature forces you to make a saving throw, you have advantage on the roll.

description.p: Physicians are those that bring their considerable intellect to bear to heal the sick and wounded. They spend their time studying the inner workings of mortal beings, their anatomies and physiologies, so they may keep their companions in top fighting condition. They use their extensive knowledge of medicine to tend and minister to those in need who don't have access to the luxury of arcane or divine healing magic.

div.p: As a Physician, you have spent a significant amount of time studying the practice and application of medical techniques. You can make Intelligence (Medicine) checks in addition to Wisdom (Medicine) checks to diagnose illnesses, recall information on diseases, and other uses of the Medicine skill relevant to your game setting.

description.p: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level, your studies allow you to use Medicine as an Intelligence-based skill. You gain proficiency in the Medicine skill and with the herbalism kit, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Medicine or with the herbalism kit you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

In addition, your time studying anatomy allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's current amount of hit points.

sheet.description: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make with your herbalism kit. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's current amount of hit points.

description.p: Your study of medicine allows you to tend to your allies even in the midst of battle. Starting at 3rd level, you can use an action on your turn to do one of the following:

Adrenaline Boost. A humanoid creature you touch can use its reaction to repeat a saving throw to end one of the following conditions affecting it: blinded, charmed, deafened, frightened, or poisoned. It gains a bonus to its roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

Crippling Strike. You target an anatomical weak point of your foe. Make a weapon attack against a creature. On hit, in addition to the normal effects of the attack, you reduce the movement speed of the target by an amount equal to 5 times your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 5 feet). This speed reduction lasts until the start of your next turn.

Dress Wounds. You soothe the aches and pains of your allies. At the end of a short rest you can touch a number of creatures, including yourself, equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). They immediately gain temporary hit points equal to 1d6 + your proficiency bonus.

Healing Surge. You use medicinal techniques to stimulate healing. A humanoid creature you touch can use its reaction to expend 1 of their Hit Die. The target immediately regains hit points equal to their Hit Die roll + their Constitution modifier + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

Stabilize. You use your knowledge to stabilize a creature. You touch a living humanoid creature that has 0 hit points and it becomes stable. The creature can then choose to expend 1 of their Hit Die to regain hit points equal to the maximum value of the Hit Die + their Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: You can do one of the following: Adrenaline Boost, Crippling Strike, Dress Wounds, Healing Surge, or Stabilize.
You can do one of the following: Adrenaline Boost, Crippling Strike, Dress Wounds, Healing Surge, or Stabilize.

description.p: Beginning at 7th level, you have mastered moving about the battlefield unscathed in order to administer aid to your allies. If you restore hit points, grant temporary hit points, or stabilize another creature, you gain the effects of the Dodge action until the start of your next turn.
In addition, when you use your Combat Medic feature, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action on that turn.

sheet.description: If you restore hit points, grant temporary hit points, or stabilize another creature, you gain the effects of the Dodge action until the start of your next turn. In addition, when you use your Combat Medic feature, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action on that turn.

description.p: When you reach 13th level, your knowledge of medicine allows you to perform greater feats of healing, both on and off the battlefield. You gain access to the following additional options for your Combat Medic feature:

Restorative Boost. You touch a humanoid creature and alleviate a debilitating effect. You end any reduction to one of the target's ability scores, end an effect reducing the target's hit point maximum, reduce its exhaustion level by one, or end one of the following conditions on it: blinded, charmed, deafened, frightened, paralyzed, or poisoned.
Resuscitate. You touch a humanoid creature that has died within the last minute. It is returned to life with 1 hit point as if you had cast the revivify spell on the creature.
Once you use one of these Combat Medic options, you can't use either again until you complete a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You gain access to the following additional options for your Combat Medic feature: Restorative Boost, or Resuscitate.

description.p: Your knowledge of medicine and the inner workings of the mortal bodies is peerless. Starting at 17th level, whenever you restore hit points or grant temporary hit points to a creature, it gains the maximum amount, in place of rolling.
In addition, any creature within 30 feet of you that expends Hit Dice to regain hit points at the end of a short rest can treat the expended Hit Dice as their maximum roll.

sheet.description: Whenever you restore hit points or grant temporary hit points to a creature, it gains the maximum amount, in place of rolling. In addition, any creature within 30 feet of you that expends Hit Dice to regain hit points at the end of a short rest can treat the expended Hit Dice as their maximum roll.

description.p: In every society there are those that look to deceive, swindle, and take advantage of common trust — thieves' guilds that run racketeering schemes, monsters that can shift their form to trick the innocent, and those who abuse their legitimate authority for personal gain. Standing in their way is the archetypal Seeker, those who use their considerable intellect to outwit any who obfuscate the truth.

As a Seeker, you excel at uncovering secrets and unraveling mysteries. You rely on your sharp eye for detail, but also on your finely honed ability to read the words and deeds of other creatures to determine their true intent. You excel at rooting out monsters that hide among, and prey upon ordinary folk, and your mastery of observation and your keen wit make you well equipped to expose, and defeat, hidden evils.

div.p: Most official classes in Dungeons & Dragons 5e have a subclass whose theme and mechanics reinforce the base identity of the class. Like the Champion fighter, the Thief rogue, or the Life Domain cleric, the Seeker serves this role for the savant. This Academic Discipline doubles down on the identity of the savant and its base class features without adding too much complexity.

description.p: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you gain an enhanced ability to discern fact from fiction. You gain proficiency in the Insight and Investigation skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Insight or Investigation you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

In addition, your familiarity with those who thrive on deception allows you to glean additional information from observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the its alignment, if the creature's current appearance is its true form, or identify which, if any, Charisma skills they are proficient in.

sheet.description: When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the its alignment, if the creature's current appearance is its true form, or identify which, if any, Charisma skills they are proficient in.

description.p: Your experience searching for the facts has honed your ability to sense deception. Starting at 3rd level, you have advantage on any ability check you make to see through an illusion or to determine if a creature is lying to you.

In addition, your heightened sense of observation enhances your abilities in combat. When you hit the target of your Adroit Analysis with a weapon attack, you can roll your Unyielding Mind die and add the result to the damage roll.

sheet.description: You have advantage on any ability check you make to see through an illusion or to determine if a creature is lying to you. When you hit the target of your Adroit Analysis with a weapon attack, you can roll your Unyielding Mind die and add the result to the damage roll.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, the speed at which you are able to react to the world around you allows you to better defend yourself from incoming blows. When you are targeted by an attack, you can use your reaction to roll your Unyielding Mind die and add it to your AC against the triggering attack. This bonus only applies against the triggering attack, after which, your Armor Class returns to normal.

sheet.description: When you are targeted by an attack, you can use your reaction to roll your Unyielding Mind die and add it to your AC against the triggering attack. This bonus only applies against the triggering attack, after which, your Armor Class returns to normal.

description.p: You can focus your considerable intellect to succeed at tasks that, to others, may seem impossible. Beginning at 13th level, when you make an attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis, or an ability check using a skill or tool you are proficient in, you can choose to substitute the d20 with your Intelligence score, instead of rolling. You must choose to use this feature before you roll.
If you use this feature for an attack roll, replacing your roll with a 20 (or higher) is the same as rolling a critical hit.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you make an attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis, or an ability check using a skill or tool you are proficient in, you can choose to substitute the d20 with your Intelligence score, instead of rolling. You must choose to use this feature before you roll. If you use this feature for an attack roll, replacing your roll with a 20 (or higher) is the same as rolling a critical hit.

description.p: Upon reaching 17th level, your keen insight into the weak points of your enemies allows you and your allies to exploit them with ruthless efficiency. When you use your Potent Observation reaction on an attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis, you can turn the attack into an automatic critical hit as part of the same reaction, in addition to adding the normal bonus damage from Potent Observation.
Once you use this feature you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: When you use your Potent Observation reaction on an attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis, you can turn the attack into an automatic critical hit as part of the same reaction, in addition to adding the normal bonus damage from Potent Observation.

description.p: Every successful monarch, conquerer, or revolt often has a master strategist that is directly responsible for their success in battle. Known as Tacticians, these strategists strive to stay one step ahead of their enemies, and make sure to have a plan for every eventuality. While they may not claim victory in each individual battle, they look to ensure victory in the war.

You have studied the art of war and the history of conquest. You know the strategies that lead to glorious victory, and the tactics that end in ruin. Alone you are no threat, but with powerful allies to direct, you are a force to be reckoned with.

When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level, you dedicate yourself to the study of warfare. You gain proficiency in the History skill, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency. If you are already proficient in History you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

You have also learned to arm yourself for battle. You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and martial weapons that lack the heavy property. In addition, when you have light or medium armor equipped, you can use your Intelligence, in place of Dexterity, when calculating your Armor Class.

Your combat experience allows you to learn information through observation. When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its Armor Class or one damage resistance, immunity, or vulnerability it has.

sheet.description: When you mark a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its Armor Class or one damage resistance, immunity, or vulnerability it has.

description.p: Beginning at 3rd level, you can use your tactical knowledge to issue commands your allies. As an action on your turn, you can issue an Order to one creature, other than yourself, within 30 feet that can see or hear you. When you issue an Order, choose from the options detailed below.

Attack Order. Your Order emboldens an ally to take the offensive. The next time the creature targeted by this Order takes the Attack action before the start of your next turn, they can make one additional weapon attack as part of that action.

Defensive Order. Your Order motivates an ally to better protect themselves. Until the start of your next turn, the creature targeted by this Order gains a bonus to their Armor Class equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

Rallying Order. Your Order provides strategic insight to an ally moving about the battlefield. A creature targeted by this Order can use their reaction to immediately move up to their speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Steadfast Order. Your Order inspires creatures to stand their ground and give no quarter. A creature targeted by this Order can add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) to any Strength or Constitution checks or saving throws they make before the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: You can issue an Order to one creature, other than yourself, within 30 feet that can see or hear you. When you issue an Order, choose from: Attack Order, Defensive Order, Rallying Order, or Steadfast Order.

description.p: Your position as a leader on and off the battlefield doesn't allow you to succumb to your base instincts. Beginning at 7th level, you are immune to the frightened condition.

In addition, you have learned to guide your allies even as you fight. When you use an action on your turn to issue an Order, you can make one weapon attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis as a bonus action on that turn.

sheet.description: When you use an action on your turn to issue an Order, you can make one weapon attack against the target of your Adroit Analysis as a bonus action on that turn.

description.p: Starting at 13th level, your experience as a leader on the battlefield allows you to command multiple allies. When you issue an Order, you can issue the same order to one additional creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you.

sheet.description: When you issue an Order, you can issue the same order to one additional creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you.

description.p: Your tactical mind places you among the greatest military commanders of history, and your presence on the battlefield inspires heroic action in those who fight alongside you. Upon reaching 17th level, when you target a creature with one of your Orders, it gains temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
In addition, when you issue an Order you can issue the same Order to one additional creature (three creatures total).

sheet.description: When you target a creature with one of your Orders, it gains {{int-mod:min-one}} temporary hit points. In addition, when you issue an Order you can issue the same Order to one additional creature (three creatures total).
